Comment:
In the past I have had trouble against the kings gambit, so it was good to get this win. Although technically it was on time-out, the match was effectively over.
The game highlights the need to use moves effectively when material down, otherwise any positional or attacking advantage can be eroded
Kings gambit accepted
Kings gambit accepted
Kings gambit accepted
I have been well beaten using this line in other games, but have learnt from past mistakes.
I have been well beaten using this line in other games, but have learnt from past mistakes.
Prevents Ne5 attacking the weak f7 square
Prevents Ne5 attacking the weak f7 square
Grabbing the centre powerfully
Grabbing the centre powerfully
Grabbing the centre powerfully
Securing the flank, and unpinning the queen from protection of the g5 pawn. With whites control of the centre, I need to develop quickly, and hopefully castle queenside since the kingside is now weak
Aiming his knight at the d5 square. Another strong move is c3, opening up lines for his queen.
Developing, and pressuring his d4 pawn.

Usually moving the same piece twice in the opening should be avoided, but guidelines should be followed in light of the position. Nothing else is any better, and this move does present a threat and reinforces whites pressure in the centre.
Developing another piece and moving closer to being able to castle if things get hairy
The computer prefers d5 or Qd3, but neither are particularly exciting. And given that white is a pawn down, he needn't worry about material, and should look to open lines
Allowing the pawn to capture exd6 would open lines in front of my king, and the move d5 simply loses the pawn. So I reason this is my best chance of keeping whites major pieces away from my king
Moving to recapture the pawn on e5, aswell as removing a queenside defender should I choose to castle that way. Re1 is stronger since the knights protection of the pawn can be removed

A weak move, I suspect white forgot his original plan or made this move without considering the position (ie part of a combination worked out earlier and not rethought). I am forced to move the bishop, but the position remains closed which is to my advantage

A weak move, I suspect white forgot his original plan or made this move without considering the position (ie part of a combination worked out earlier and not rethought). I am forced to move the bishop, but the position remains closed which is to my advantage
Finally plays the rook move, but with the bishop unpinned and sitting where it is I have a defense
Finally plays the rook move, but with the bishop unpinned and sitting where it is I have a defense
Nulls the threat of the knight
Removes the pin, once again threatening Nxe5
Defending the backwards pawn, and blocking the white d-pawn. Another possibility is an immediate f5, but I didn't want to expose my king too much or offer any counterplay
Defending the backwards pawn, and blocking the white d-pawn. Another possibility is an immediate f5, but I didn't want to expose my king too much or offer any counterplay

The knight can be routed to g6 to defend the pawn, and from it's current position puts pressure on the white d-pawn

A largely meaningless move, although it does serve to complicate the position after d6, although I decided there was little threat from this move.
Another option is moving the bishop to d2 and unleashing the other rook
